children.subject:
As far as I know, Stat 2 and 20 cover material very similar to AP stats so they might not be worth taking for you. Since CS C8 + Stat 88 is equivalent to Stat 20 for many major pre-reqs, that combination would repeat much of AP stats as well.
Also, CS 61A has a lot of overlap with CS C8 on the programming side, so most of C8 may seem repetitive.

There are people who do take both 61A and C8 if they're interested in data science. I think others can comment better on this.

CS 70 is significantly more work and higher difficulty than C8 (and likely Econ 1 or 2). Depending on your past math experience, it might be a good choice, but EE 16AB are classes that are supposed to foster the "sophomore mathematical maturity" for 70.

history.content:
Graduating senior here, studied Math/Stats/CS. If you're an incoming freshman, I wouldn't take CS 61A and CS 70 together in the same semester, especially your first. The transition from high school life to college life can be quite overwhelming (newfound freedom, personal responsibility for motivation), and 61A and 70 are both workload intensive courses for new college students. Take your time and absorb the material; there's no need to feel rushed to "get things done." You can easily find yourself overwhelmed by projects and the problem sets (the problem sets in CS 70 take A LONG time, especially if you have no previous college-level math experience. Proof-based mathematics is very different from computation-based math you see in high school/Calculus). 

Here's also another big tip: don't rely too much on AP course experience/knowledge! Yes, having previous exposure can and will be helpful, but I can personally tell you expectations from AP courses/exams are a lot different from expectations in college, especially Berkeley. It varies by professor, but you really need to be able to internalize the material well (which I didn't really feel was true for AP exams and courses).

Here's what I'd personally take your first semester:

CS 61A, EE 16A, Stat 2, Breadth/C8/Class that sounds interesting to you (I personally recommend Astro C12/13! very cool and interesting class with an easy workload)

These are just my 2 cents from my experience in Berkeley. Don't feel rushed to take as many classes as possible. Remember, there's more to the college experience than academics, especially freshman year. Focus on both academics and social/personal life, without focusing too heavily on one, and your freshman year will be great. :)

EE 16a prepares you for CS 70, so you should not take CS 70 your first semester. I'd say your second schedule is your best bet. If you do not get into CS 195, I suggest looking into DeCals! I would strongly advise against taking 18 units your first semester at Cal.... You will be going through a lot of changes in your lifestyle. Play it safe for your first semester.

-Halley, Current Student who has taken these courses

EE 16a prepares you for CS 70, so you should not take CS 70 your first semester. I'd say your second schedule is your best bet. If you do not get into CS 195, I suggest looking into DeCals! I would strongly advise against taking 18 units your first semester at Cal.... You will be going through a lot of changes in your lifestyle. Play it safe for your first semester.

children.subject: CS 70 during semester moves fast and also goes deep. Homework and tests are really hard. Don't suggest take it during first semester. Also, linear algebra prepares you for the regression part of CS 70.
#2 seems best, #3 also okay, and good that you can drop something if it's too much.

Would recommend #2.

CS70 is not a class you want to take first semester freshman year. I took it after taking a decent amount of math classes here (Math1B, Stat20, Math53, Math54) and it was still very difficult for me.

Depending on how you feel about statistics, I would not recommend taking Stat2 if you already done well in AP Stats (Stat20 for me was very redundant). I also think stat88+data8 is pretty much stat20 so take that into consideration. Maybe you want to check out some other connector course instead.

why is it that EE 16A "prepares" students more than Math 54 for CS70? is it just recommended for cs majors? I am trying to decide if I should take EE 16A or Math 54 for preparation for CS 70, and am confused if the content in EE 16a is actually more relevant to CS 70 then Math 54. Thanks!

history.content:
As I am trying to finalize my schedule, I am looking for input from students for my freshman first semester schedule. I am currently contemplating between 

Schedule One: CS 61A,  CS 70, EE 16 A, Stat 2, which from what I've heard is three heavy courses and one light one with prior AP statistics

16 Units

Schedule Two: CS 61A, EE 16A, CS C8, Stat 88, CS 195 Waitlist

Since the world is becoming so dependent on data, I am interested in learning about some data science.

15 Units 

Schedule 3: Econ, CS 61A, EE 16A, CS C8, Stat 88

For this schedule if it got too difficult, I would either drop Stat 88 or Econ.

18 Units

Please let me know based on your experiences in these classes and the difficulty of them , which one you would recommend.

Note: Do not worry about pre-reqs, I have met all those already.
history.subject: CS61A, CS 70,EE16A, Stat 2 or CS61A,EE16A, CS C8, Stat 88, or Econ, CS61A, EE16A, CS C8,Stat 88
